key_points: Dominick Black, 19, of Racine, pleaded not guilty to charges of providing Kyle Rittenhouse, then 17, an AR-15-style rifle.
Black faces two counts of providing a dangerous weapon to someone under 18, resulting in death, with each count potentially carrying a three-year prison sentence.
Black's attorney, Anthony Cotton, filed a motion to dismiss the charges, claiming a misinterpretation of the law.
The rifle was purchased for Rittenhouse to use on private property and was stored in Kenosha by Black's stepfather.
Rittenhouse used the rifle in August in Kenosha to fatally shoot two protesters and wound a third, claiming self-defense.
Wisconsin law prohibits adults from providing firearms to minors, with certain exceptions for supervised activities.
Cotton argues that the law's exceptions and specifications do not apply because Rittenhouse was not hunting.
A separate motion by Cotton challenges the charging of two counts for the same weapon transfer, citing double jeopardy concerns.
Judge Bruce Schroeder indicated agreement on the multiplicity issue and will likely issue a ruling in writing by June.
Federal authorities are considering charges against Black for straw purchasing the rifle, potentially facing up to 10 years in prison.
